attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    On 31st May 2025, a physical stock count of raw materials and finished products was carried out at the Crater branch to verify inventory accuracy by comparing physical counts with SAP system records and to evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of existing stock control measures.
•    A few discrepancies in the inventory records were observed as illustrated below:
a)    Bread stock had a surplus  of 28 Pieces,
b)    Polybags had a surplus of 1,669 pieces,
c)    White flour had a surplus of 8.45 kgs,
d)    Wheat bran had a surplus of 7.32kgs,
e)    Brown flour had a surplus of 1.54kgs,
f)    Yeast had a surplus of 1.2 sachets,
g)    Other stock items had minimal variation as illustrated below;
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Crates Movement.
•    A physical count of crates at the branch was conducted to assess the effectiveness of crate movement controls.
•    The results indicated that there were opening balance amounting to 102 crates nonetheless, the crates balance tallied.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should review and update the Bill of Materials to reflect actual consumption rates, and ensure production staff adhere strictly to standardized recipes to prevent ingredient overuse or underuse.
attributes.effect: •    The observed variances, though relatively minor, highlight inconsistencies in inventory management practices. Discrepancies between BOM and actual ingredient usage indicate potential overuse or underuse of materials, affecting production cost control and operational efficiency.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Surpluses in bread, polybags, and ingredients indicate BOM variances and inventory recording gaps.
Remediation Plan:

  • Review and align the Bill of Materials (BOM) with actual usage.

Issue: No variance noted; crate controls are effective.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain regular documentation to sustain zero variance.

  • Continue enforcing crate movement reconciliation at dispatch and return points.

value:
•    Many stock items are having minimal variations. We also had instances of remixes therefore not utilizing fully the ingredients thus the noted variation.
•    We shall however try to ensure branch is having less or no variations.

•    Occasionally, there are discrepancies between the Bill of Materials (BOM) and the actual yield.
•    We shall ensure proper controls are in place to minimize variations.
•    The positive variance in polybags may be due to certain items containing additional pieces.
•    Crate balances are well managed through regular audits conducted at key branches.
•    Any discrepancies identified are addressed through appropriate deductions.

•    In the prior audit report dated 15th   April 2025 stock take reveled the following:
a)    Polybags +1,109 Pieces.
b)    Bread stock had a negative variance of 18 Loaves.
c)    White flour had a variance of -1.828.
d)    All other materials had negligible variations.
e)    Crates had nil variance.
Previous

A physical stock count was conducted on 31st May 2025 at the Crater branch. This aimed to identify discrepancies between physical and system-recorded stock for raw materials, finished products and crates.

Although the variances were minor and most items matched well, the few discrepancies observed suggest there’s a need for tighter monitoring and periodic updating of the Bill of Materials (BOM). Crate records were accurate, reflecting strong controls in crate movement.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of recorded inventory by comparing SAP records to actual physical stock, and to assess the effectiveness of stock and crate management controls.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
period of 31 days from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025.
•    This analysis aimed to assess whether the average yield per production bag and actual Utto consumption aligned with the set BOM, evaluate the full utilization of branch production capacity and ensure compliance with quality standards.
•    The analysis revealed the following:
a)    Utto consumption stood at 100%.
b)    The average yield was 191.47 loaves per bag.
c)    Average production was 73.81 bags per day, this represents 76.09% of the set target of 97 bags.
d)    There were 144 remixes for the period audited.
•    Below is a summary of the audit finding:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should also strengthen the accuracy of daily sales forecasts to better match production volumes to optimize daily output without overproducing or even under producing.
attributes.effect:
•    While aligning production with daily sales helps minimize wastage, it also limits capacity utilization and makes it harder to achieve set production targets especially if daily demand fluctuates.
•    Equipment failures (like oven issues) cause remixes and production delays undermining efficiency and potentially compromising product quality and delivery schedules.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Production only achieved 76.09% of target; 144 remixes due to oven issues.
Remediation Plan:

  • Improve preventive maintenance scheduling for critical machines like ovens.

  • Forecast daily production based on expected demand and capacity.

  • Reduce remixes through equipment reliability and process discipline.

value:
•    Our daily production is based on actual sales, so we aim to keep bread balance at the branch to a minimum.
•    However, this sometimes makes it difficult to meet our production targets
•    Remixes occur mainly due to oven breakdowns at the branch. These issues are usually reported promptly while awaiting technical support from KAF.

•    Our production is driven by daily sales and we aim to minimize bread balances at the branch level.
•    However, this approach can hinder the achievement of our production targets. 
•    At times, our production operates at full capacity especially when bread transfers are made to other branches.

•    In Prior Audit, audit findings were as follows: 
a)    Average production was 73.17 bags equivalent to 75.05% of the set target of 97.5bags.
b)    Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
c)    The average yield was 191.44 loaves per bag.

The audit reviewed mixing charts for May 2025 to evaluate yield per bag, Utto consumption, remix frequency, and production efficiency. It also examined whether the branch was achieving its daily production targets.

Production was at 76.09% of the set target, largely due to oven issues and daily sales-based planning. While waste was minimized, efficiency suffered. Strengthening equipment reliability and sales forecasting is necessary.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if the branch is achieving optimal production levels, following the Bill of Materials (BOM), and efficiently using inputs like Utto and yeast.

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was carried out to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded cash balance in the cash flow records. This was also intended to assess the effectiveness of cash handling and management controls.
•    At the time of our audit, physical cash tallied with the recorded cash balance in the cash flow. However, there was pending IOUS dated 17th May 2025 amounting to Kshs 1,800 for Hassan and IOU dated 27th May 2025 for Akot amounting to kshs 250
Implication:
•    The fact that physical cash tallied with recorded balances indicates that cash handling controls at the branch are generally sound and being properly followed.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management to maintain the existing controls at the branch which has been effective
attributes.effect: •    The fact that physical cash tallied with recorded balances indicates that cash handling controls at the branch are generally sound and being properly followed.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: IOUs of Kshs 2,050 pending; physical cash tallied.
Remediation Plan:

  • Follow up to clear IOUs within 3days of issuance.

  • Maintain a daily IOU log and follow up promptly.

  • Retain strong internal controls as currently implemented.

value:
•    Cash Controls at the branch are operating effectively and thus we shall maintain.
•    Follow up on pending IOUS shall be done to ensure they are cleared.
•    Cash Controls at the branch are operating effectively and thus we shall maintain.

•    In prior audit, there was there was a negligible variance of KES +38 arising from cents difference during casual workers’ payment.
•    There were 2 pending IOUs dated 9th March (KPLC facilitation for outage fixing) & 10th April worth KES 4,200
Previous
A spot check on cash was done as part of standard internal controls. The audit verified whether the actual cash matched the book balance and checked for any undocumented transactions.

The physical cash matched the recorded cash balance, indicating that controls are functioning well. However, there were two pending IOUs that need prompt follow-up to avoid future reconciliation issues.
Finance Department
To confirm that the physical cash held at the branch matches the recorded balance and to assess adherence to proper cash handling procedures.

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted on 31st May 2025 to assess whether the weight of packed bread, ready for market dispatch, complied with the required KEBS standard weights.
•    The audit involved sampling various bread types to evaluate weight accuracy.
•    The analysis revealed notable instances of non-compliance, particularly underweight products across several bread varieties. While some samples met or exceeded the required weight, a significant portion fell below the standard weight.
•    Summary of findings:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should regularly monitor and ensure calibration of weighing equipment to ensure they are dispensing accurate weights.
•    Supervisors should follow up to ensure all dividing and packing processes align with approved production standards.
attributes.effect:
•    Inconsistent product weights indicate non-compliance with standard operating procedures and a lack of control in the production process.
•    Under-weight products may result in customer dissatisfaction and loss of consumer trust affecting sales and brand credibility.
•    Overweight products increase production costs and reduce overall profitability by consuming excess raw materials.
•    Failure to meet KEBS weight standards could lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and potential financial losses.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: High percentage of underweight loaves, especially in 800g, 600g, and 400g varieties.
Remediation Plan:

  • Calibrate weighing machines 

  • Ensure compliance to dividing range, cooling time and packing weight.

value:
•    We experienced remix cases due to oven breakdowns and frequent power disruptions. The generator, when run for extended periods, cannot effectively support both ovens, which contributed to some of the underweight cases observed.
•    Additionally, the ovens are aging and not dependable for maintaining consistent weight control, as prolonged baking leads to moisture loss.

•    We shall do follow up to ensure dividing ranges are as per the standards.
•    Some of the underweight cases observed were caused by moisture loss, which happened because the bread was baked for too long.

•    The previous audit report dated 14th   April 2025; underweights percentage noted were as follows:
a)    400g Ct-27%,
b)    600g Ct-12%,
c)    600g Barrel-35%,
d)    800g-17%.
•    Overweight across the branch variety were as shown below:
e)    400g Ct-2%,
f)    600g Ct-7%,
g)    600g Barrel-9%,
A sample weight check was performed on various bread types ready for dispatch. The test sought to assess compliance with standard bread weights and detect production inconsistencies.

High rates of underweight products were found, especially for 400g and 800g varieties. This raises concerns over equipment performance and process consistency. Calibration of weighing scales and oven efficiency must be prioritized.
Operations/Production Department
To verify if all bread produced complies with KEBS weight standards and to ensure quality consistency across varieties.

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An analysis was done on the bread damage levels for both production and market-based damages for the period 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025 to detect if the quality standards set for the branch were being followed.
•    We noted the following:
a)    Production bread damages stood at 0.29% of total production which was slightly above the set limit of 0.2% 
b)    Market damage stood at 1.35% of total sales, which was within the set limit of 0.5% as demonstrated in the table below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Regular damage monitoring and root cause analysis is necessary in order to track trends and take timely corrective action.
•    Branch management should use market return data to identify common defects and link them to specific production shifts, routes or sales merchandisers for targeted improvements.

•    Branch management should ensure all bread damages, including those sent to the ingredients department and moldy disposals, are promptly and accurately recorded in the designated book.
attributes.effect:
•    Production bread damages at 0.29% exceeded the set Key Performance Indicator (KPI) of 0.2%, indicating inefficiencies or lapses in the production process.
•    Although market damage stood at 1.35%, far above the KPI threshold of 0.5% this suggests quality control issues and has potential long-term effects on customer satisfaction and brand reputation.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Production damages at 0.29% and market damages at 1.35%, both exceeding KPIs.
Remediation Plan:

  • Request additional or replacement ovens to minimize deformities.
  • Strengthen quality control and monitor market returns trend to identify key trends and adopt corrective measures. 

Issue: Unaccounted variance of 53 kg (133 loaves); moldy disposals not recorded.
Remediation Plan:

  • Record every disposal and transfer to the ingredients department immediately.

  • Reconcile physical, manual and system balances to prevent accumulation of unaccounted damages

value:
•    We are requesting a lottery oven to help support the existing ovens, reduce their workload, and improve overall efficiency, which will in turn help minimize  damages both at the market level and production.

•    The controls are effective we shall ensure proper documentation is always done and maintained
•    We are disposing the moldy separately which can contribute to slight variance noted.

•    Oven breakdowns have resulted in product deformities leading to a high volume of returns from the market
•    We are seeking support from the maintenance team to help ensure the ovens operate within acceptable limits and reduce such occurrences.
 •    Manager has been advised to do proper recording of damages to avoid any variations and appropriate control measures will be enhanced.

•    During the prior audit dated 14th April 2025, it was noted that;      
a)    Production damages were 0.207% of the total production,
b)    Market damages were 1.31% of the total sales.
An analysis covering May 2025 assessed damage percentages from production processes and from returns in the market, to determine the effectiveness of quality control measures.

Both production (0.29%) and market (1.35%) damage levels exceeded set limits. Production inefficiencies and poor post-production handling are key contributors. Corrective action is necessary to minimize financial losses and protect brand integrity
To evaluate levels of bread damage during production and distribution, and compare them against Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    We carried out a review to assess how well the production workforce is being utilized. The aim was to determine whether each production worker is achieving the company’s target of producing 4.5 bags, as specified in the company policy.
•    The analysis showed that the average production per worker was 4.12 bags, which is slightly below the company’s standard target of 4.5 bags per worker, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management is recommended to align staffing decisions more closely with production targets and machine availability to avoid unnecessary labor costs.
•    Branch management should also implement a preventive maintenance program for key machinery to reduce the risk of unexpected breakdowns.
attributes.effect:
•    The below-target production efficiency indicates potential operational inefficiencies that could affect overall profitability and productivity.
•    Continued equipment downtime without on-time resolution risks disrupting production schedules and meeting customer demand.
•    The extra labor costs incurred due to overstaffing highlight a misalignment between workforce planning and actual production needs, leading to increased operational expenses.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Output per worker was 4.21 bags, below the 4.5 bag target.
Remediation Plan:

  • Adjust staffing based on daily production trends.

  • Implement machine maintenance schedules to avoid disruptions.

  • Track individual performance and reassign underperforming staff if needed.

value:
•    We had instances of breakdowns of machines, slicers and oven we communicated on time although we had slow responses.
•    We shall try to improve efficiency at the branch to match the expected

•    With the noted issues of machines breakdown it largely affected the efficiency attainment.
•    We shall follow up to ensure alignment of workers with production to enhance efficiency attainment.
•    The previous audit report indicated a production efficiency of 4.20 bags per production worker.
Production staffing and output for May 2025 were analyzed to evaluate workforce utilization and cost efficiency. The focus was to identify overstaffing or operational inefficiencies.

The branch achieved 4.21 bags per worker, slightly below the target. Overstaffing and machinery breakdowns were identified as major contributors. Staffing should be aligned with actual needs and preventive maintenance should be improved
To determine if the number of production workers aligns with actual output, based on the company’s benchmark of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was carried out to evaluate the efficiency of packers in the slicing section, focusing on whether they met the company’s standard target of 97 crates per packer.
•    The analysis covered a period of 31 days from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025. The results showed that the average packing efficiency was 84.36 crates per packer, which is below the target, as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should review and adjust staffing levels regularly to align packer numbers with actual production volumes, avoiding unnecessary labor costs.
attributes.effect:
•    The shortfall in packing efficiency indicates a mismatch between workforce allocation and actual production output, resulting in unnecessary labor costs and reduced cost-effectiveness.
•    The continued employment of underperforming slicers and packers points to insufficient performance monitoring and lack of corrective action and or training, which may contribute to long-term inefficiencies.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Achieved 84.36 crates per packer vs. 97 target; resulted in excess packers and cost impact.
Remediation Plan:

  • Repair slicing and coding machines promptly.

  • Align packer numbers with actual production volumes.

value:
•    Coding machine had some issue which is yet to be repaired.
•    The KAF repair took quite some time.
•    Lack of Spare parts has been rampart across the period. Supply on this items is quite scare as this are comments that we receive from the technical team.

•    Slicing machines had major breakdowns which affected efficiency attainment.
•    We shall follow up with KAF to ensure timely repair and make it possible for slicers to attain the efficiency.
•    The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 93.49crates per packer.
Packing efficiency was evaluated for May 2025 to determine if labor resources were optimally used and if equipment or process issues affected productivity.

The branch achieved 84.36 crates per packer, well below the target. Staffing was excessive and equipment breakdowns affected performance. Regular monitoring and timely maintenance are needed to boost output.
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether packers in the slicing section meet the company’s productivity target of 97 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted at the Mini Shop on 1st June  2025, to verify that all bread available for sale was properly recorded and to confirm that reported sales matched the amounts received through the assigned pay bill number, since the shop operates on a cashless basis.
•    We found that all sales recorded up to the time of the spot check were accurate.
•    In addition, the physical bread stock, including all deliveries and top-ups, was present as expected excluding the quantities already sold.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should continue enforcing the current stock tracking and cashless sales controls as they are effective in ensuring accuracy and transparency.
attributes.effect: •    The effective stock controls in the Mini Shop indicate that all sales and bread movements are accurately recorded, minimizing discrepancies.
attributes.remediation_plan:
ssue: Accurate reconciliation with a minor variance of Ksh 4.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain current controls and real-time reconciliation practices.

  • Set up separate till numbers for each mini-shop for clearer tracking.

value:
•    Controls in place shall be maintained.
•    We are requesting diff till numbers for the both minishop
•    We are requesting diff till numbers for the both minishop
A spot check was conducted on 1st June 2025 to verify that bread sales and physical stock at the Mini Shop matched with Mpesa collections and system records.
Records were accurate with only a negligible variance of KES 4. The shop’s stock and sales controls are strong and should be maintained, with minor improvements to till account separation.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm the accuracy of stock movement and Mpesa sales collection in the branch’s cashless mini shop.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review was conducted on the branch of vehicles’ fuel consumption to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period up to 29th  May 2025
Finding:
•    KCL 218R Town route had a faulty speedometer which has not yet been repaired.
•    Other routes fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Continue issuing fuel based strictly on kilometers covered as per route. 
•    This policy has proven effective in controlling fuel use and aligning consumption with operational demands.
attributes.effect: •    The issue with the speedometer malfunction on the Town route vehicle could lead to inaccurate fuel tracking, making it difficult to monitor actual consumption and potentially masking other underlying problems.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Town route vehicle has a faulty speedometer.
Remediation Plan:

  • Repair or replace the faulty speedometer to restore tracking.

  • Continue issuing fuel based on actual km covered, with daily log entries.

value:
•    We shall ensure vehicles with speedometer issues has been rectified.
•    Motor Vehicle   KBW 475P shall be closely monitored.
•    Manager to continue issuing fuel in accordance to km covered.
•    During the previous audit it was noted that the actual fuel consumption for each vehicle was within the set standard.
The audit reviewed vehicle mileage and fuel consumption data up to 29th May 2025. It also checked for proper functioning of mileage tracking systems.
Most vehicles were within acceptable limits except one (Town route) with a faulty speedometer. This needs urgent repair to restore full monitoring capability and control.
Transport/Fleet Department
To monitor fuel usage against distance covered to detect inefficiencies or misuse, and assess vehicle tracking reliability.

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review of the debtors’ balances as of 31st  May 2025 was carried out to identify any outstanding amounts at the branch that may pose a risk of becoming bad debts.
•    It was noted that there were a few outstanding balances and no dormant accounts were observed excluding institutional accounts.. Our review only looked at clients who owed amounts and didn’t receive any supply the next day. This could increase credit risk for the branch, as these clients might become inactive and affect sales by not paying their dues  as detailed below,
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management and sales team should maintain strict debt management controls to prevent overdue balances from accumulating.
attributes.effect: These accounts may be at risk of becoming dormant, increasing the likelihood of bad debts. If not addressed promptly, this could negatively impact cash flow and overall sales performance, as non-performing clients hinder revenue recovery and disrupt the supply cycle
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Few outstanding balances but well-managed accounts.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain strict follow-ups and enforce deposit policy.

  • Flag overdue accounts for weekly review.

  • Monitor institutional accounts closely due to larger balances.

value: •    The sales representative will follow up on these outstanding accounts to ensure the balances are fully cleared.
•    The sales representative will follow up on these outstanding accounts to ensure the balances are fully cleared
•    The previous audit report indicated an  outstanding debt for customers and schools mounting to KES 805,711.97
A review of the debtors' list as at 31st May 2025 was done to identify any overdue or unsecured debts and determine how well credit controls are being enforced.
Debt management is effective, with only a few pending balances and no dormant accounts. Continued vigilance is necessary to prevent credit risks.
Sales Department
To evaluate the status of outstanding customer balances and assess the risk of bad debts.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We evaluated the generator's fuel consumption from May 1, 2025, to May 31st 2025, to assess its efficiency and ensure it operated within expected parameters.
•    Based on the collected data, the results were deemed reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this period as seen below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure fuel consumption remains within reasonable limits and that the physical fuel balance is accurately recorded.
attributes.effect: The generator’s fuel usage was within expected limits, indicating efficient operation with no signs of fuel misuse or mechanical issues during the reviewed period
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: No issues noted; performance is within expectations.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain regular monitoring and logging.

  • Continue tracking usage against operational hours to detect inefficiencies early.

value: •    Controls in place are effective we shall maintain.
•    Controls in place are effective we shall maintain.
Generator use and fuel consumption from May 1–31, 2025, were analyzed to assess control effectiveness and detect any irregular usage or recording errors.
Fuel consumption was within expected parameters and accurately documented. The controls are effective and should be maintained.
Transport/Fleet Department
To confirm that generator fuel consumption is within acceptable efficiency levels and correctly recorded.

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit verification was conducted on 28th May 2025 to confirm that all bread damages declared as sent to the ingredients department were either physically available or correctly accounted for according to the established procedures.
•    The review covered the period from 1st May 2025 to 31st May 2025 and identified a variance of 53 kg, equivalent to 133 loaves, which could not be accounted for in either physical stock or recorded.
•    Additionally, it was noted that some instances of moldy bread disposal were not recorded, indicating gaps in documentation and accountability.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure all bread damages, including those sent to the ingredients department and moldy disposals, are promptly and accurately recorded in the designated book.
attributes.effect:
•    The unaccounted 133 loaves represent a loss of both product and value, suggesting weak internal controls in handling and recording bread damages.
•    Failure to record disposed moldy bread and transferred damages undermines the integrity of inventory records and hinders effective tracking and reconciliation.
•    Inadequate oversight in the handling of bread damages increases the risk of unauthorized diversion or misappropriation of stock.

value:
•    The controls are effective we shall ensure proper documentation is always done and maintained
•    We are disposing the moldy separately which can contribute to slight variance noted.
•    Manager has been advised to do proper recording of damages to avoid any variations and appropriate control measures will be enhanced.
•    In the previous audit report, for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025, damages had a variance of -972.30 Kgs equivalent to -2,430.75 Loaves.
A reconciliation of bread damages and physical stock was done for May 2025. The aim was to ensure that all damaged or returned bread was accurately tracked and transferred to ingredients or disposal.

A variance of 53kg (approx. 133 loaves) was found. This suggests weak controls in recording and tracking damages, especially for moldy or discarded items. Proper documentation procedures must be enforced.
To confirm that bread damage reported as sent to the ingredients department is properly recorded and accounted for.
